awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Quantum-Safe Cryptosystems Based on Isogenies
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research into the security of a new family of cryptosystems based on a mathematical structure called isogenies of elliptic curves. The research will also include the development of new isogeny-based protocols. These protocols are among the front runners in the process of replacement of the current public key primitives by alternatives that will be secure against attacks by quantum computers.  The transition towards a quantum-safe cyberspace is an immediate priority for the cryptography community. Indeed, quantum-safe primitives will need to be ready and deployed long before the construction of large scale quantum computers to account for the shelf life of encrypted data. This research has broader impacts to industry which will need to follow recommendations for a secure use of isogeny cryptosystems. It also impacts education through the development of new cybersecurity curriculum at the university and high school level. 

This project will involve the analysis of the hardness of the task of finding an isogeny between two given elliptic curves over a finite field. In particular, new quantum algorithms will be developed for computing isogenies. The careful analysis of the performances of these algorithms is the indicator of the security of isogeny-based schemes. It will permit the identification of an appropriate size for keys that keep users out of the reach of quantum attacks. The project will also explore new applications of cryptographic primitives based on isogenies. Efficient solutions for static-static key exchange protocols will be investigated. These primitives also have potential for ring signatures that can have many practical applications including anonymous transactions on the blockchain, and quantum-safe anonymous cryptocurrencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of South Florida,Mathematics and Statistics

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This award has supported research into the security of a new family of cryptosystems based on a mathematical structure called isogenies of elliptic curves. The research has also included the development of new cryptographic protocols based on cryptographic group actions. These protocols include certain isogeny-based primitives, which are among the front runners in the process of replacement of the current public key primitives by alternatives that will be secure against attacks by quantum computers. The transition towards a quantum-safe cyberspace is an immediate priority for the cryptography community. Indeed, quantum-safe primitives will need to be ready and deployed long before the construction of large scale quantum computers to account for the shelf life of encrypted data. This research has had broader impacts to industry which will need to follow recommendations for a secure use of isogeny cryptosystems. It has also impacted education through the development of new cybersecurity curriculum at the university and high school level.

The concrete research outcomes of this project are two-fold:
a) The security of existing proposals has been studied, and new attacks have been described.
b) New cryptographic schemes were introduced.

As part of this project, the PI has analysed the hardness of the task of finding an isogeny between two given elliptic curves over a finite field. In particular, new quantum algorithms were developed for computing isogenies. The careful analysis of the performances of these algorithms is the indicator of the security of isogeny-based schemes. It permits the identification of an appropriate size for keys that keep users out of the reach of quantum attacks. The PI was able to describe new algorithms with better asymptotic complexity than the state of the art, and he also provided concrete cost analyses to make key size recommendations to achieve the security levels identified by NIST for its ongoing standardization process of post-quantum cryptographic schemes. 

As part of this project, the PI also explored new applications of cryptographic primitives based on hard cryptographic actions. The PI co-designed a new code-based digital signature scheme called LESS based on the action of the group of permutations on linear codes. The PI contributed to the analysis of LESS and the demonstration that its performances were on par with the best available code based signatures. Moreover, the PI showed that LESS could also offer ring signatures that can have many practical applications including anonymous transactions on the blockchain, and quantum-safe anonymous cryptocurrencies. The PI also showed that LESS could be adapted to provide identity-based signatures.

The broader impacts of this project included the inception of an annual cybersecurity summer camp running free of charge at the USF, as well as new cryptography curriculum at the undergraduate and graduate level.



Last Modified: 09/24/2021
Modified by: Jean-Francois Biasse
por.por_txt_cntn:
This award has supported research into the security of a new family of  cryptosystems based on a mathematical structure called isogenies of  elliptic curves. The research has also included the development of new cryptographic protocols based on cryptographic group actions. These protocols include certain isogeny-based primitives, which are among the front runners in  the process of replacement of the current public key primitives by  alternatives that will be secure against attacks by quantum computers.   The transition towards a quantum-safe cyberspace is an immediate  priority for the cryptography community. Indeed, quantum-safe primitives  will need to be ready and deployed long before the construction of  large scale quantum computers to account for the shelf life of encrypted  data. This research has had broader impacts to industry which will need to  follow recommendations for a secure use of isogeny cryptosystems. It  has also impacted education through the development of new cybersecurity  curriculum at the university and high school level. 


The concrete research outcomes of this project are two-fold: 
a) The security of existing proposals has been studied, and new attacks have been described. 
b) New cryptographic schemes were introduced.

As part of this project, the PI has analysed the hardness of the task of finding an  isogeny between two given elliptic curves over a finite field. In  particular, new quantum algorithms were developed for computing  isogenies. The careful analysis of the performances of these algorithms  is the indicator of the security of isogeny-based schemes. It permits the identification of an appropriate size for keys that keep  users out of the reach of quantum attacks. The PI was able to describe new algorithms with better asymptotic complexity than the state of the art, and he also provided concrete cost analyses to make key size recommendations to achieve the security levels identified by NIST for its ongoing standardization process of post-quantum cryptographic schemes. 

 As part of this project, the PI also explored  new applications of cryptographic primitives based on hard cryptographic actions. The PI co-designed a new code-based digital signature scheme called LESS based on the action of the group of permutations on linear codes. The PI contributed to the analysis of LESS and the demonstration that its performances were on par with the best available code based signatures. Moreover, the PI showed that LESS could also offer ring signatures  that can have many practical applications including anonymous  transactions on the blockchain, and quantum-safe anonymous  cryptocurrencies. The PI also showed that LESS could be adapted to provide identity-based signatures. 

The broader impacts of this project included the inception of an annual cybersecurity summer camp running free of charge at the USF, as well as new cryptography curriculum at the undergraduate and graduate level.
